content:
Intro # Hello friends, this will be me kinda taking notes on how I set up my server for future reference and for funsies. I actually got an insane deal on the server I got, its a 10 year old gaming PC however for the low low price of 70 dollaridoos so pretty happy with that. It was on windows of course so I first downloaded a Ubuntu server ISO(basically a file for putting that OS on your computer) and set that all up. I then exchanged SSH keys between this server and my computer so I could work on it from my main computer(I used the ssh-copy-id command). Ill include stuff I looked at below.
Hardening SSH # Im gonna do this section in a kinda step format because im not so sure how to format it. The config file is in /etc/ssh/sshd_config btw.
Change my port for SSH away from the default of 22 Set these configs to no PasswordAuthentication noPermitRootLogin no Run this command to only allow SSH connections from your IP, also make sure you install iptables-persistent for the file to save to. #Basically what its doing is making a rule for incoming connections(-A INPUT) for TCP(-p TCP) at the port of your SSH port(--dport <your ssh port>) -s from your address (-s <your ip address>)allow them into the SSH(-j ACCEPT) if that rule doesn't happen then the same thing but don't let them into the SSH(-j DROP) also save it using that last line.sudo iptables -A INPUT -p tcp --dport <your ssh port> -s <your ip address> -j ACCEPTsudo iptables -A INPUT -p tcp --dport <your ssh port> -j DROPsudo iptables-save | sudo tee /etc/iptables/rules.v4 Stuff I looked at # Harden your Linux server: Best practices for securing SSH,User Privileges, firewall configurations
title: Server Hardening

content:
First Hugo post # Hello, this will be my first hugo posts basically documenting firstly my experience on getting it to work
I mostly use my arch linux laptop that I use for school but I was setting it up on my desktop using WSL(Windows Sub-System for Linux) a thing to let me run linux things on my windows computer
I was using the Hugo theme ‘blowfish’ for this setup so some things may not be applicable if you are using another theme.
Ps. some of my links may be outdated if you are viewing this in the far future.
Installing Hugo # Now this was one of the more tedious parts as I did not know about the different package managers not having the latest versions but the steps are basically:
Ensure you have a package manager that has the latest version of Hugo, I used brew(Click for that here) because apt didn’t have the lastest enter this code to install brew install hugo Check youve installed it using hugo version Creating a new site with a theme # This part could be different based on what theme you chose but I used blowfish as my theme
Type hugo new site <your website name> to create the directory structure for your site like a skeleton Type cd <your website name> to enter that directory Type git init to initialise that reposistory into a git repository Was told idk blah blah (link to website for hugo themes here) In your current directory you should see a hugo.toml file, delete it and replace it with a folder config/_default and then take the .toml files from themes/<theme name>/config/_default and put them inside Customising # You can now get to customising and adding things to your website, testing by typing hugo server to set it up locally
Check your hugo.toml to set your base url as well as your theme, to prevent confusion this is the theme you just installed like blowfish Check your languages.toml file and edit all the values to your liking such as your name Check your params.toml, here you will be able to set things like light/dark mode, default settings and your theme for website(For all options click here) Making first post # Most commonly in Hugo your posts are gonna be made in Markdown files which look like this(Cheat sheet in references below): Make a new folder inside your content folder for neatness so you can keep related posts together e.g Writeups Place a new Markdown file inside and follow the cheat sheet to create your own post You can also create a front header that helps you change the settings of the post it looks like: ---title : 'Figuring out hugo'description : "First post gonna be my process of figuring out hugo for me to post my writeups"category : ['writeups']tags : ['Hugo']date : 2025-09-17draft : falseshowAuthorBottom: true--- All front matter settings here
References # Brew package manager Hugo quickstart guide Hugo themes Blowfish theme guide Markdown cheat sheet
title: Figuring out hugo

content:
Overview # In this project my team built a social media site to help combat the growing issue of lonliness in elderly. The website featured many features such as communities and posting to those communities to allow users to share about common interests and learn about new ones. My role in this project was mainly to help with managing those posts and communities, suspicious logins and customer support using Gemini
However unlike the previous project this one had a much stronger focus on application security and helped me to learn about common vulnerabilities and how to combat them using the OWASP top 10.
Tech Stack # Backend: Python Flask Database: SQL Front-end: HTML, Bootstrap, Jinja2 Templating, Javascript
Features I Made # Creation,viewing and joining of communities Creation,viewing and liking of posts 2FA (Sending email) New device verification New location login warning Rate limiting CSRF Protection Error Handling Open redirect protection Search Home Page Chatbot Conclusion # Although this project was much harder I felt it was way more fun as it was closer to my course in cyber security. It also serverd as a great learning oppurtunity to get familiar with common vulnerabilities and SQL.
Skills learned Through the Features # SQL Database Management Flask Email Burp Suite What exactly is sent in HTTP requests Web Cookies Common vulnerability prevention Gemini API
title: Application Security Project

content:
Overview # In this project I aimed to bring more convenience to customers through the power of e-commerce. I did this through, with my group, building a working shopping website that had features to both make the lives of the people managing and shopping on the website easier. For this website I developed the Displaying of listings, The shopping cart, Checking out , Displaying the customers orders as well as all orders for the people running the website, Email receipts and a Chat-bot.
In order to do all of this I have used Python, HTML, Flask, JavaScript and Jinja to work on this project as a team. To implement more features I also had to use APIs such as Gemini for the chat bot and Pandas for creating excel sheets as well as Libraries such as Creditcard to verify credit cards.
Features I made # Gemini Chat-bot Exporting customer orders to excel for data analysis Filters for any pages displaying items Cart that is session based Storage of order and product data Customers are emailed their receipts Protection from Cross-Site-Scripting Validation for forms and carts Checking images MIME type to ensure its file type Virus scanning on images uploaded Meta-Data scrubbing on images uploaded Conclusion # All these features would aim to help customers to have a smooth experience with thoughtful design as well as the people managing the website to help them to manage the place easily and also make future plans using the data that they collect through customers contacting them and order data analysis.
The parts I made also had an emphasis on security and redundancy which would help the managers to feel safer that they are not very prone to bugs or attacks such as cross-site-scripting.
Skills learned Through the Features # Gemini API Pandas Python Library Managing website Sessions Shelve Python Library Flask Email WTForms library Checking file MIME type ClamAV library for Virus Scanning How to look at and remove Meta-Data
title: Clothing E-commerce shop(app development project)
